pullrequest.title: updating head to initial MultiSense SL model, with temporary unsynchronized streams.

content.raw:
This looks like a potential race condition: two threads check `ros::isInitialized()`, find it false, then both threads proceed to initialize ROS in parallel.

Can we push initialization of ROS for all ROS-enabled plugins to somewhere that is guaranteed to be run serially during startup?
content.html:
This looks like a potential race condition: two threads check ros::isInitialized(), find it false, then both threads proceed to initialize ROS in parallel.

Can we push initialization of ROS for all ROS-enabled plugins to somewhere that is guaranteed to be run serially during startup?

pullrequest.title: updating head to initial MultiSense SL model, with temporary unsynchronized streams.

content.raw: This whole block can be removed if the check for `ros::isInitialized()` is moved into `Load()` and is used to gate the creation of this thread.
content.html: This whole block can be removed if the check for ros::isInitialized() is moved into Load() and is used to gate the creation of this thread.

pullrequest.title: updating head to initial MultiSense SL model, with temporary unsynchronized streams.
updating head to initial MultiSense SL model, with temporary unsynchronized streams.

content.raw:
Using a leading slash in a topic (or other ROS resource) name prevents namespace push down.  Better to say, in this case, `multisense_sl/status`.  If not in a namespace, the result will be the same.

So as to not delay the 1.2 release, this can be ticketed for later if you prefer.

Btw, this comment applies throughout to other topic names (probably also in other plugins).  I won't comment on them individually.
content.html:
Using a leading slash in a topic (or other ROS resource) name prevents namespace push down. Better to say, in this case, multisense_sl/status. If not in a namespace, the result will be the same.

So as to not delay the 1.2 release, this can be ticketed for later if you prefer.

Btw, this comment applies throughout to other topic names (probably also in other plugins). I won't comment on them individually.

pullrequest.title: updating head to initial MultiSense SL model, with temporary unsynchronized streams.

content.raw:
Suggest doing `this->rosnode_ = new ros::NodeHandle();` (i.e., no ~) to create a node handle operating in the parent namespace.  Then the leading slashes can be removed without changing where the topics appear in the common case.  Need to test that, as I may be misremembering how namespaces work.

Make sure to check how `this->rosnode_` is used.  E.g., if you're retrieving private params, you may want to create another handle via `"(~)"`.
content.html:
Suggest doing this->rosnode_ = new ros::NodeHandle(); (i.e., no ~) to create a node handle operating in the parent namespace. Then the leading slashes can be removed without changing where the topics appear in the common case. Need to test that, as I may be misremembering how namespaces work.

Make sure to check how this->rosnode_ is used. E.g., if you're retrieving private params, you may want to create another handle via "(~)".

content.raw: Minor: if you're not going to put other logic in here, then I don't think that you need to use the connect and disconnect callbacks.  You can query the ros::Publisher object for its subscriber count via [getNumSubscribers()](http://ros.org/doc/api/roscpp/html/classros_1_1Publisher.html#ad56c8e954020290dcb87cd6bbd330a2b).
content.html: Minor: if you're not going to put other logic in here, then I don't think that you need to use the connect and disconnect callbacks. You can query the ros::Publisher object for its subscriber count via getNumSubscribers().

pullrequest.title: updating head to initial MultiSense SL model, with temporary unsynchronized streams.

content.raw:
I think you're missing a link on the laser - it should be head -> nodding_link -> head_hokuyo
The point of that extra link is that it densifies the laser point cloud even when the robot is standing perfectly stationary.

Question T172 from DARPA: 
How many degrees of freedom does the LIDAR mount have? 	
A. Two ‐a nodding 'yes' motion up and down, and a rotational DOF above the nodding joint about the head's x‐axis (forward facing axis).
content.html:
I think you're missing a link on the laser - it should be head -> nodding_link -> head_hokuyo The point of that extra link is that it densifies the laser point cloud even when the robot is standing perfectly stationary.

Question T172 from DARPA: How many degrees of freedom does the LIDAR mount have?
A. Two ‐a nodding 'yes' motion up and down, and a rotational DOF above the nodding joint about the head's x‐axis (forward facing axis).

pullrequest.title: updating head to initial MultiSense SL model, with temporary unsynchronized streams.

content.raw:
Hi Maurice,

The "nodding" joint is the `neck.ay` joint.

Note though the head appears to be "floating" for now, the offsets are correct, but the `utorso` link has not been updated to the new structure so it connects with the sensor joint location.  There will be mesh updates as soon as the new structure CAD/mesh is available.

John
content.html:
Hi Maurice,

The "nodding" joint is the neck.ay joint.

Note though the head appears to be "floating" for now, the offsets are correct, but the utorso link has not been updated to the new structure so it connects with the sensor joint location. There will be mesh updates as soon as the new structure CAD/mesh is available.

John

pullrequest.title: updating head to initial MultiSense SL model, with temporary unsynchronized streams.

content.raw: Ok, I guess that the answer to T172 is actually wrong then. It implies that the lidar itself has two DOFs - independent of the rest of the head. My bad
content.html: Ok, I guess that the answer to T172 is actually wrong then. It implies that the lidar itself has two DOFs - independent of the rest of the head. My bad

pullrequest.title: updating head to initial MultiSense SL model, with temporary unsynchronized streams.

content.raw: I didn't read that as you're wrong, the lidar mount is the [head link](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/3e342da8b0fab8c1a320c32d3afbec27ead38f88/models/drc_robot/model.urdf?at=multisense_no_vrc#cl-7), and if you count both the [neck_ay joint](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/3e342da8b0fab8c1a320c32d3afbec27ead38f88/models/drc_robot/model.urdf?at=multisense_no_vrc#cl-761) and the [hokuyo joint](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/3e342da8b0fab8c1a320c32d3afbec27ead38f88/models/drc_robot/model.urdf?at=multisense_no_vrc#cl-63) then all is well :)
content.html: I didn't read that as you're wrong, the lidar mount is the head link, and if you count both the neck_ay joint and the hokuyo joint then all is well :)
